title.rendered: Top U.S. Travel Blogger Sees Emerging Trend in 2023

content.rendered:
A collage of History Gems

Escape the Present. Discover the Past.

Past Lane Travels blog logo

Owner of the #1 USA History and Travel blog says THIS is where travelers are going on vacation.

It’s not just about visiting museums or historical sites, but learning about the traditions, food and culture of a region to connect with the past.”

— Jessica James

GETTYSBURG, PA, US, May 3, 2023/EINPresswire.com/ — Jessica James, an award-winning historical fiction author and owner of Past Lane Travels blog, predicts that historical destinations will benefit from a growing trend in travel throughout 2023.

“I’ve talked to fellow travelers everywhere I go, and they’re sticking closer to home and making historical destinations part of their plans,” James said. “Everything is coming together to make history a focal point for travel.”

There is a good bit of data to back up that prediction. Whether it’s because of rising fuel prices, unpredictable airline disruptions, or the uncertain economic outlook, the latest statistics show that travelers are prioritizing domestic destinations.

The U.S. Travel Association reports that domestic leisure travel in 2023 has surpassed pre-pandemic levels, and Grand Welcome [https://www.grandwelcome.com/blog/1155/majority-of-americans-are-traveling-this-summer-and-spending-more-than-last-year-despite-cost-of-living-increases/

], a short-term vacation rental management franchise, found that 80 percent of their survey respondents plan to stay in the United States for their vacations.

Additionally, 59 percent of respondents in an Expedia survey said they expect to plan travel within the U.S., either instead of or in addition to foreign trips. [https://www.forbes.com/advisor/credit-cards/travel-rewards/travel-trends-predictions-2023/#:~:text=Though%20international%20travel%20may%20look%20affordable%2C%20the%20reality,instead%20of%20or%20in%20addition%20to%20foreign%20trips.]

Another sign that points to a change in interest for travelers is a survey by GetYourGuide. Ninety percent of the respondents said they want to “experience a destination like a local.” [https://www.forbes.com/advisor/credit-cards/travel-rewards/travel-trends-predictions-2023/#:~:text=Though%20international%20travel%20may%20look%20affordable%2C%20the%20reality,instead%20of%20or%20in%20addition%20to%20foreign%20trips.]

“These results reflect a growing appreciation for the rich history and cultural heritage that the United States has to offer, with travelers seeking to understand and explore their own country’s roots,” James said. “It’s not just about visiting museums or historical sites, but learning about the traditions, food and culture of a region to connect with the past.”

Going hand-in-hand with this idea is the opportunity to forge human connections by really getting to know a community rather than just visiting as a tourist. This also helps travelers support local economies and communities while giving a needed boost to local tourism industries.

“I think travelers understand that by visiting historical destinations within the United States, they are not only increasing their knowledge about important events or places, but also directly supporting local businesses and heritage preservation efforts,” James said.

Another factor James believes may be driving this trend is the increasing recognition of the importance of learning from history—and preserving it.

Historical destinations, ranging from national landmarks to small-town museums, offer unique insights into the stories, struggles, and achievements of the past, allowing visitors to gain a deeper understanding of our country’s heritage—at a time when some are trying to erase or destroy it.

“Visiting historical sites—even if they are close to home—helps provide opportunities for reflection, education and dialogue,” James said. “Learning about the past can be something that unites rather than divides.”

James believes that travelers seeking to connect with their roots and contribute to local economies will make historical destinations a popular travel objective this year. “I think we’ll see even more emphasis on history and culture in 2023, and a renewed focus on putting historical destinations on travel bucket lists.”

As the owner of the #1 history and travel blog, James hopes the trend continues and points out that a historical destination doesn’t have to be a major excursion.

“You’d be surprised how much history you can discover within an hour’s drive,” James said. “Historical destinations can be a fun day trip, a weekend getaway or a major road trip that the entire family can help plan.”

Even if you’re someone who prefers sitting on the beach during your hard-earned vacation time, there are lots of interesting sites within a 30 minute drive that can make a fun trip on a rainy day. And whether you’re interested in visiting a historic city like Savannah, GA, or a small town like Gettysburg, PA, there are countless opportunities to immerse yourself in the fascinating history of the United States.

Anyone seeking inspiration or ideas about interesting historical destinations to visit can learn more at Past Lane Travels.

“A trip back in time can start in your own hometown,” James said.

Jessica James
Past Lane Travels

5 Historic Sites To Visit In The USA

News Provided By

May 03, 2023, 15:30 GMT
